_**Succession**_ is an American [drama](/wiki/Drama_\(film_and_television\)
"Drama \(film and television\)") television series about a dysfunctional
American global-media family that premiered on June 3, 2018, on
[HBO](/wiki/HBO "HBO"). It was created by [Jesse
Armstrong](/wiki/Jesse_Armstrong "Jesse Armstrong") with [Will
Ferrell](/wiki/Will_Ferrell "Will Ferrell") and [Adam McKay](/wiki/Adam_McKay
"Adam McKay") serving as executive producers. McKay also directed the pilot
episode. In June 2018, it was announced that the series had been renewed for a
second season.

##
Premise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Premise")]

_Succession_ follows "the Roy family – Logan Roy and his four children – who
control one of the biggest media and entertainment conglomerates in the world.
The series tracks their lives as they contemplate what the future will hold
for them once their aging father begins to step back from the company."[1]

## Cast and
characters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast and characters")]

###
Main[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Main")]

  * [Hiam Abbass](/wiki/Hiam_Abbass "Hiam Abbass") as Marcia "Marcy" Roy, the third wife of Logan Roy.
  * [Nicholas Braun](/wiki/Nicholas_Braun "Nicholas Braun") as Greg Hirsch, the great-nephew of Logan Roy and grandson of Ewan Roy.
  * [Brian Cox](/wiki/Brian_Cox_\(actor\) "Brian Cox \(actor\)") as Logan Roy, the founder of media and entertainment conglomerate Waystar Royco.
  * [Kieran Culkin](/wiki/Kieran_Culkin "Kieran Culkin") as Roman Roy, the third and youngest son of Logan Roy from his second marriage.
  * [Peter Friedman](/wiki/Peter_Friedman "Peter Friedman") as Frank Vernon, the COO of Waystar Royco and long time confidante of Logan Roy.
  * [Natalie Gold](/wiki/Natalie_Gold "Natalie Gold") as Rava Roy, the separated wife of Kendall Roy.
  * [Matthew Macfadyen](/wiki/Matthew_Macfadyen "Matthew Macfadyen") as Tom Wamsgans, the fiance of Shiv Roy.
  * [Alan Ruck](/wiki/Alan_Ruck "Alan Ruck") as Connor Roy, the eldest son of Logan Roy from his first marriage.
  * [Parker Sawyers](/wiki/Parker_Sawyers "Parker Sawyers") as Alessandro Daniels, an executive of Waystar Royco present during the Vaulter acquisition meetings.
  * [Sarah Snook](/wiki/Sarah_Snook "Sarah Snook") as Siobhan "Shiv" Roy, the youngest child and daughter of Logan Roy from his second marriage.
  * [Jeremy Strong](/wiki/Jeremy_Strong_\(actor\) "Jeremy Strong \(actor\)") as Kendall Roy, the second son of Logan Roy from his second marriage.
  * Rob Yang as Lawrence Yee, the founder of media website Vaulter that is acquired by Waystar Royco.

###
Recurring[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Recurring")]

  * Scott Nicholson as Colin, Logan's [body man](/wiki/Body_man "Body man").
  * [J. Smith-Cameron](/wiki/J._Smith-Cameron "J. Smith-Cameron") as Gerri Killman, general counsel to Waystar Royco.
  * [David Rasche](/wiki/David_Rasche "David Rasche") as Karl, a member of Waystar Royco's legal team.
  * [Arian Moayed](/wiki/Arian_Moayed "Arian Moayed") as Stewy Hosseini, a financier and friend of Kendall's who becomes a member of Waystar Royco's board.
  * [Ashley Zukerman](/wiki/Ashley_Zukerman "Ashley Zukerman") as Nate Sofrelli, a political strategist and former romantic partner of Shiv's. He convinces her to work on the Eavis presidential campaign and the two of them are having an affair.
  * Juliana Canfield as Jess Jordan, Kendall's assistant.
  * [Dagmara Domińczyk](/wiki/Dagmara_Domi%C5%84czyk "Dagmara Domińczyk") as Karolina, a member of Waystar Royco's legal team.
  * [Justine Lupe](/wiki/Justine_Lupe "Justine Lupe") as Willa, Connor Roy's young girlfriend.
  * Peggy J. Scott as Jeane, Logan's secretary.
  * [Judy Reyes](/wiki/Judy_Reyes "Judy Reyes") as Eva, a member of Waystar Royco's legal team and an executive producer at ATN, a news channel owned by Waystar Royco.
  * [Eric Bogosian](/wiki/Eric_Bogosian "Eric Bogosian") as Gil Eavis, a liberal presidential candidate whom Nate introduces to Shiv. He is vocally opposed to Waystar Royco's attempted takeover of local news networks and becomes a target of their cable news network ATN because of it.
  * Swayam Bhatia as Sophie Roy, Kendall's daughter.
  * Quentin Morales as Iverson Roy, Kendall's son.
  * Molly Griggs as Grace, Roman's girlfriend whom he breaks up with after she tells him that she enjoyed _The Biggest Turkey in the World_ , a film Roman tried to kill while working in Waystar Royco's film division.
  * [Larry Pine](/wiki/Larry_Pine "Larry Pine") as Sandy Furness, the owner of a rival media conglomerate who plots a hostile takeover of Waystar Royco with Kendall.
  * [Caitlin FitzGerald](/wiki/Caitlin_FitzGerald "Caitlin FitzGerald") as Tabitha, a woman who gave Tom a blowjob at his bachelor party and whom Roman is now dating.
  * [Mary Birdsong](/wiki/Mary_Birdsong "Mary Birdsong") as Marianne, Logan's niece and Greg's mother.
  * Jake Choi as Tatsuya, an associate of Lawrence.
  * [Eisa Davis](/wiki/Eisa_Davis "Eisa Davis") as Joyce Miller, the former [Attorney General of New York](/wiki/Attorney_General_of_New_York "Attorney General of New York") elected to a seat in the [United States Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") for whom Shiv serves as a political strategist.
  * [James Cromwell](/wiki/James_Cromwell "James Cromwell") as Ewan Roy, Logan's estranged brother and Greg's grandfather who resides in Canada.
  * Darius Homayoun as Amir, Marcy's son who announces at Thanksgiving dinner that he has been hired to head Waystar Royco's animation division in Europe.
  * [Harriet Walter](/wiki/Harriet_Walter "Harriet Walter") as Caroline Collingwood, the second wife of Logan Roy and Kendall, Shiv, and Roman's mother.
  * [Jack Gilpin](/wiki/Jack_Gilpin "Jack Gilpin") as Mr. Wamsgans, Tom's Father.
  * [Kristin Griffith](/wiki/Kristin_Griffith "Kristin Griffith") as Mrs. Wamsgans, Tom's mother and a highly-respected attorney in the [Minneapolis–Saint Paul](/wiki/Minneapolis%E2%80%93Saint_Paul "Minneapolis–Saint Paul") area.

###
Guest[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Guest")]

  * [Mark Blum](/wiki/Mark_Blum "Mark Blum") as Bill ("Sad Sack Wasp Trap"), the retiring head of Waystar Royco's Adventure Parks division.
  * [Annika Boras](/wiki/Annika_Boras "Annika Boras") as Anna Newman ("Sad Sack Wasp Trap"), an on-air personality at ATN, the news network owned by Waystar Royco, that Kendall takes to the family's annual charity event, the Roy Endowment Creative New York (RECNY) ball.
  * [David Patrick Kelly](/wiki/David_Patrick_Kelly "David Patrick Kelly") as Paul Chambers ("Which Side Are You On?"), a member of Waystar Royco's board that votes against a vote of no confidence in regards to Logan.
  * [Griffin Dunne](/wiki/Griffin_Dunne "Griffin Dunne") as Dr. Alon Parfit ("Austerlitz"), a corporate therapist hired to work with the Roy family as Logan attempts to rehabilitate their public image.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Development")]

On June 6, 2016, [HBO](/wiki/HBO "HBO") announced that they had given the
production a pilot order.[12] The episode was set to be written by [Jesse
Armstrong](/wiki/Jesse_Armstrong "Jesse Armstrong") and directed by [Adam
McKay](/wiki/Adam_McKay "Adam McKay"). Executive producers for the pilot were
to include Armstrong, McKay, [Will Ferrell](/wiki/Will_Ferrell "Will
Ferrell"), [Frank Rich](/wiki/Frank_Rich "Frank Rich"), and Kevin
Messick.[13][14][15][16] On May 16, 2017, it was announced that HBO had given
the production a series order for a first season consisting of ten episodes.
The previously announced creative was expected to continue their involvement
as the series enters into production.[17][18][19][20][21][22]

On November 17, 2017, it was announced that [Nicholas
Britell](/wiki/Nicholas_Britell "Nicholas Britell") would serve as the series'
composer.[23] On April 26, 2018, it was announced that the series would
premiere on June 3, 2018.[24]

On June 11, 2018, it was announced that HBO had renewed the series for a
second season.[25]

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Casting")]

On October 6, 2016, it was announced that [Brian
Cox](/wiki/Brian_Cox_\(actor\) "Brian Cox \(actor\)"), [Jeremy
Strong](/wiki/Jeremy_Strong_\(actor\) "Jeremy Strong \(actor\)"), [Kieran
Culkin](/wiki/Kieran_Culkin "Kieran Culkin"), [Sarah Snook](/wiki/Sarah_Snook
"Sarah Snook"), [Nicholas Braun](/wiki/Nicholas_Braun "Nicholas Braun"), and
[Matthew Macfadyen](/wiki/Matthew_Macfadyen "Matthew Macfadyen") had been cast
in lead roles in the series' pilot.[26] On November 4, 2016, it was announced
that [Hiam Abbass](/wiki/Hiam_Abbass "Hiam Abbass"), [Alan
Ruck](/wiki/Alan_Ruck "Alan Ruck"), Rob Yang, Parker Sawyers, and [Peter
Friedman](/wiki/Peter_Friedman "Peter Friedman") had also joined the main cast
of the pilot.[27]

On January 24, 2018, it was reported that [Ashley
Zukerman](/wiki/Ashley_Zukerman "Ashley Zukerman") had joined the series in a
recurring role.[28] On March 7, 2018, it was reported that Jake Choi had been
cast in a recurring role.[29]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Filming")]

Principal photography for the first season of the series began in October 2017
in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") at locations including
Lexington Avenue and East 75th Street.[30] During the week of November 20,
2017, production took place in the [Financial
District](/wiki/Financial_District,_Manhattan "Financial District, Manhattan")
of [Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan").[31] In December 2017, the series
was reportedly in production on the sixth episode.[32] From mid-January 2018
to the end of the month, the production moved from New York to [New
Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico").[33][34][35][30] Filming reportedly
took place around the [Santa Fe](/wiki/Santa_Fe,_New_Mexico "Santa Fe, New
Mexico") area of the state.[36] On February 22, 2018, filming took place in
[New Jersey](/wiki/New_Jersey "New Jersey") which required the closing of the
Atlantic City-Brigantine tunnel.[37][38][39] On February 25, 2018, filming
took place at [Eastnor Castle](/wiki/Eastnor_Castle "Eastnor Castle") near
[Ledbury](/wiki/Ledbury "Ledbury") in [Herefordshire](/wiki/Herefordshire
"Herefordshire"), [England](/wiki/England "England").[40]

###
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Marketing")]

On January 18, 2018, HBO released the first teaser trailer for the
series.[41][42][43] On March 27, 2018, a second teaser trailer was
released.[44] On April 26, 2018, the first full trailer was released.[45]

###
Premiere[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Premiere")]

On April 27, 2018, the series held its official world premiere during the
Series Mania Festival in [Lille, France](/wiki/Lille "Lille") in which the
pilot episode was screened.[46] On May 22, 2018, the series held its official
US premiere at the [Time Warner Center](/wiki/Time_Warner_Center "Time Warner
Center") in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").[47]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Critical response")]

The series has been met with a positive response from critics upon its
premiere. On the review aggregation website [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the series holds a 86%
approval rating with an average rating of 7.2 out of 10 based on 57 reviews.
The website's critical consensus reads, "The spectacle of rich people behaving
badly makes _Succession_ entertaining, but only up to a point."[48]
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), which uses a weighted average,
assigned the series a score of 70 out of 100 based on 29 critics, indicating
"generally favorable reviews."[49]

###
Ratings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Succession_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Ratings")]

Media outlets have characterized the show's ratings as "fairly low" and
"bordering on miniscule."[50][51] The premiere episode drew 582,000 viewers,
down from the 1.39 million viewers that watched its [lead-in](/wiki/Hammocking
"Hammocking") _[Westworld](/wiki/Westworld_\(TV_series\) "Westworld \(TV
series\)")_.[2]
